title: Hearing Assistive Technology: A Viable Alternative to Hearing Aids
chief_complaint: I have lost three pairs of hearing aids in the past two years and I am not sure how it happens. My daughter says my TV is too loud and I recently had trouble with the bank because I misunderstood a voicemail.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty understanding speech on the telephone and television; vague reporting of listening difficulties.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Frustration with losing devices; social activities limited to family visits and church; reliance on daughter for IADLs.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Desires to improve hearing for TV, telephone, and conversations at home, but has a history of losing devices.

history.present_illness: Patient attended alone. Reported losing 3 pairs of HAs (2 BTE, 1 RIC) in 2 years. Unsure how loss occurred. Lives alone, 'quiet' lifestyle.
history.otologic_history: No specific history of ear surgery or infection mentioned.
history.medical_psych_history: Cognitive status concerns noted (vague reporting, repeats herself, strays from topic). Limited vision and manual dexterity identified.
history.prior_management: Previous use of BTE and RIC hearing aids, all lost.
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing without losing the devices.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical gradually sloping mild to severe sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT consistent with pure tone average. Word recognition scores excellent (96%) bilaterally, suggesting normal ability to recognize speech at elevated levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, middle ear pressure, and static admittance bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Self-report scales
tests.key_findings: HHIE score indicates mild perceived handicap. COSI identified specific needs.

numeric_results.COSI_Priority_1: Conversations at home - living room with family members
numeric_results.COSI_Priority_2: Telephone - conversations with family, unfamiliar voices, voicemails
numeric_results.COSI_Priority_3: Television - volume too loud for others

history.present_illness: Follow-up for hearing aid fitting. Patient accompanied by daughter.
history.medical_psych_history: Daughter observed to be uninterested and unengaged.
history.prior_management: Decision made to proceed with hearing aid trial despite history of loss.
history.patient_goals: Fit new devices with retention security.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Fitting
tests.key_findings: Fitted with mid-level full-shell ITE hearing aids. 2.5mm vent. Volume control/program button deactivated. Telecoil set to auto. Grommet and tether clip attached to prevent loss. Verified with REM.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 2 weeks post-fitting. Patient reported lack of benefit and retention issues. Hearing aids fell out multiple times and tether was disconnected. Misplaced devices for 4 days.
history.medical_psych_history: Daughter did not assist mother with devices, citing cultural respect for independence.
history.plan: Hearing aids returned for credit. Recommended HATs (Pocketalker, wireless TV headset, captioning phone).

tests.name: Device Inspection & Data Logging
tests.key_findings: Devices not properly inserted. Wrong battery size (312) used. Minimal usage recorded.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 2 weeks after HAT recommendation. Patient and daughter reported improvement in all areas.
history.outcome: Pocketalker improved conversation at home/church. Wireless headset improved TV enjoyment. Captioning phone improved telephone communication.

tests.name: COSI
tests.key_findings: Perceived improvement in all identified listening situations.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral symmetrical gradually sloping mild to severe sensorineural hearing loss with excellent word recognition abilities (96% AU). Despite good speech discrimination potential, the patient has a significant history of losing hearing aids (3 pairs in 2 years). Self-assessment (HHIE) reveals a mild perceived handicap, and COSI identifies TV, telephone, and home conversations as priority needs. Management focused on custom ITE devices with physical retention systems (tethers) to address the loss issue.
counseling_points: We have chosen custom in-the-ear hearing aids to make them easier for you to handle and see.
I have attached a special clip and tether to these aids; please clip this to your clothing every time you wear them to prevent losing them.
The volume controls are turned off for now so you don't have to worry about adjusting them.
We will practice inserting and removing the aids today, and I encourage your daughter to watch so she can help if needed.
notes_for_actor: Portray an 88-year-old woman who is pleasant but vague in her reporting.
Occasionally repeat yourself or stray from the topic of conversation.
You are frustrated about losing your hearing aids but cannot explain how or when it happens.
Your daughter (if present) should act uninterested and unengaged, checking her phone or looking away.
